articles.title: Vast Challenge 2021 Mini-Challenge 2 - with R

author.name: Chen Yuxi, Jovinka Hartanto, Lim Yong Kai

articles.contents:
The 2021 IEEE VAST Challenge brings back a classic challenge to see how approaches and techniques have developed since its original release. This year’s challenge will be a variation on a previous year’s challenge, with modified data and new questions. The following information is extracted from the Vast Challenge site.
Overview
Note: This scenario and all the people, places, groups, technologies, contained therein are fictitious. Any resemblance to real people, places, groups, or technologies is purely coincidental.
In the roughly twenty years that Tethys-based GAStech has been operating a natural gas production site in the island country of Kronos, it has produced remarkable profits and developed strong relationships with the government of Kronos. However, GAStech has not been as successful in demonstrating environmental stewardship.
In January, 2014, the leaders of GAStech are celebrating their new-found fortune as a result of the initial public offering of their very successful company. In the midst of this celebration, several employees of GAStech go missing. An organization known as the Protectors of Kronos (POK) is suspected in the disappearance, but things may not be what they seem.
As an expert in visual analytics, our group, Group 5, is called in to help law enforcement from Kronos and Tethys.
Mini-Challenge 2



Many of the Abila, Kronos-based employees of GAStech have company cars which are approved for both personal and business use. Those who do not have company cars have the ability to check out company trucks for business use, but these trucks cannot be used for personal business.
Employees with company cars are happy to have these vehicles, because the company cars are generally much higher quality than the cars they would be able to afford otherwise. However, GAStech does not trust their employees. Without the employees? knowledge, GAStech has installed geospatial tracking software in the company vehicles. The vehicles are tracked periodically as long as they are moving.
This vehicle tracking data has been made available to law enforcement to support their investigation. Unfortunately, data is not available for the day the GAStech employees went missing. Data is only available for the two weeks prior to the disappearance.
To promote local businesses, Kronos based companies provide a Kronos Kares benefit card to GASTech employees giving them discounts and rewards in exchange for collecting information about their credit card purchases and preferences as recorded on loyalty cards. This data has been made available to investigators in the hopes that it can help resolve the situation. However, Kronos Kares does not collect personal information beyond purchases.
As a visual analytics expert assisting law enforcement, your mission is to identify which GASTech employees made which purchases and identify suspicious patterns of behavior. You must cope with uncertainties that result from missing, conflicting, and imperfect data to make recommendations for further investigation.

articles.title: ISSS608 G1 Group 5 - Project Proposal

author.name: Chen Yuxi, Jovinka Hartanto, Lim Yong Kai

articles.contents:
Contents
1. Overview
2. Objectives
3. Previous Work and GIS Application
4. Data Sources
5. Methodology and Analytical Approach
6. Assumptions
7. Application Design
Data Visualisation
Application Interface


1. Overview
In the roughly twenty years that Tethys-based GAStech has been operating a natural gas production site in the island country of Kronos, it has produced remarkable profits and developed strong relationships with the government of Kronos. However, GAStech has not been as successful in demonstrating environmental stewardship.
In January, 2014, the leaders of GAStech are celebrating their new-found fortune as a result of the initial public offering of their very successful company. In the midst of this celebration, several employees of GAStech go missing. An organization known as the Protectors of Kronos (POK) is suspected in the disappearance, but things may not be what they seem.
2. Objectives
Both historical vehicle tracking data and transaction data from loyalty and credit card will be used to observe the following issues:
The most popular locations and when they are popular
Infer the owner of each credit card and loyalty card
Identify potential informal or unofficial relationships among GASTech personnel
Analyze unusual and suspicious activities of the employees
Analyze daily routines of GasTech employees
3. Previous Work and GIS Application
Geographic information system (GIS) data has been used by different business and entities for many purposes. Police agencies are using Geographic Information Systems (GIS) for mapping crime, identifying crime “hot spots,” assigning officers, and profiling offenders.
According to a 2001 survey by the National Institute of Justice, 62 percent of police departments with over 100 officers use GIS systems. Collectively, the technology has been credited with reducing crime, decreasing residential burglaries, tracking parolees and serious habitual offenders, and identifying “hot spots” with high concentrations of crime.
Is the Use of Geographic Information Systems (GIS) for Policing Effective?, 2014
4. Data Sources
The data source are available publicly on VAST Challenge 2021 website under the sub section Mini-Challenge 2. The data used for the project are as follows:



Geospatial maps of Abila and Kronos Island



Figure 1: Map of Abila, Kronos

5. Methodology and Analytical Approach
Our group aims to provide users with an interactive to derive insights from the data source. RStudio is the main software tool that will be used for analysing and developing the project artefact and output. R packages, such as dplyr, reshape2, tidyr, lubridate and tmap will be used to perform data manipulation, data transformation and geospatial plots of map. In addition, GGplot2 and Shiny will be used to create visualisations for the app.
The analytical approach of this study are as follow:
Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA): to understand the patterns and the relationship between the GPS, car assignment, and transaction data. EDA will also performed to detect any missing data, outliers, and or anomalies that might exist in the dataset
Exploratory Spatial Data Analysis (ESDA): to visualize and explore island map and GPS route and to determine the popularity for each location
Credit card and loyalty card mapping: to identify card ownership
Network analysis: to visualize and identify unusual relationship among employees and locations
R Markdown and R Shiny to prepare the report and user interface
The time frame for this project is shown below.



Figure 2: Project Gantt Chart



6. Assumptions
The main underlying assumption lies with the mapping of location details on the credit cards and loyalty cards data to the travel route of each vehicle. The data does not provide the GPS location in the credit and loyalty cards transaction data. Hence apart from assigning the various locations in the cards data with a GPS coordinate, a sorting of time stamps is also required to determine when the vehicles had become stationary. Where the vehicles stopped at is assumed to be where the employees have gone at that specific time period.
7. Application Design
Data Visualisation
Heat map to identify popular locations at various time periods
Visualize movement and temporal changes of the GPS tracking data on Abila geospatial map
Boxplot for transaction data from credit card and loyalty card
Network analysis to show potential informal or unofficial relationships among GASTech personnel and locations of visit
Application Interface
The Shiny App is envisioned to have these functionalities:
Multiple values (drop down) of employees to display moving line from GPS data on Abila map, filtered by day and time period



Figure 3: Dashboard Interface 1



Heat map and box plot filtered by location, day and time period
Interative charts with tooltips



Figure 4: Dashboard Interface 2



Mapping of credit card and loyalty card to employees



Figure 5: Dashboard Interface 3



Interactive network analysis filtered by employee, location and department



Figure 6: Dashboard Interface 4

articles.title: ISSS608 G1 Group 5 - Application User Guide
articles.description: Step-by-step guide on how the application features and functions
articles.contents:
Contents
Application
User Guide for Shiny Application
1.0 Overview
2.0 Abila Kronos Map
2.1 Filter Selection Panel
2.2 Main Visualisation Panel

3.0 Locations Transactions
3.1 Filter selection Panel
3.2 Main Visualisation Panel

4.0 Card Mapping
5.0 Network Analysis
5.1 Network Analysis by Credit Card Transaction
5.2 Network Analysis by employee car GPS locations



Application
The application designed using R Shiny is available on shinyapps.io
The source code for the R Shiny application is available on Github
User Guide for Shiny Application
1.0 Overview
Entering the application will bring the user to the overview page. The overview page summarise the background information of the mini challenge and the 5 questions that the Shiny application will answer using visual analytic tools.
The papers, documents and source code are available via the link to the website and Github.



Figure 1: Overview Tab



2.0 Abila Kronos Map
The tab plots the GPS movement data of each employee’s car.
2.1 Filter Selection Panel
On the left side panel, four filters are available for user to select multiple inputs to change both interactive visualisations. Employee, Time Period and Location are drop down filters with multiple selection available. Date is a range filter between 6 January 2014 to 19 January 2014.
Figure 2 shows selection with choices from the Employee, Time Period and Location filters, Date range of 6 to 19 January. Clicking on the Submit button will update the visualisation accordingly to the filter selections.



Figure 2: Abila Kronos Map: Filter Selection



2.2 Main Visualisation Panel
2.2.1 Map
The interactive map of Abila Kronos displays the GPS movement data of GASTech employee cars. The black lines depicts the travel path and the blue dots depicts the location where the car stop and become stationary for more than 5 minutes. User can adjust the Employee, Date and Time Period filters to focus on the GPS data plotted in the visualisation.
Figure 3 shows selection of employee Onda Marin on 6 January 2014. The map on the right panel dynamically changed after the Submit button is clicked. User can hover around the stop locations represented by blue dots to display micro data of the car owner name, time when car is stationary and its possible location.



Figure 3: Abila Kronos Map: Map of GASTech employee car GPS



2.2.2 Scatter Plot
The interactive scatter plot displays employee’s car stop location represented by a colored dot. User is able to filter the selection to drill down on specific parameters. Hovering over the dot reveal the time period and employee name of the car stop location.
Figure 4 shows the selection of location, House 2, 4, 10 and Meeting 1 to 5. User is able to drag and select a specific section to zoom in and hover over the dots to obtain micro-data.



Figure 4: Abila Kronos Map: Scatter Plot of GASTech employee car stop location



3.0 Locations Transactions
The tab analyse the credit card and loyalty card transactions details to determine the most popular locations and the spending pattern for each location.
3.1 Filter selection Panel
On the left side panel, five filters are available for user to select multiple inputs to change all 3 interactive visualisations. Location, Employee, Time Period and Department are drop down filters with multiple selection available. Date is a range filter between 6 January 2014 to 19 January 2014.
Figure 5 shows selection of all choices from the Location and Employee filters. The filters Date range is set from 12 to 19 January during the evening to night Time Period for employee in the Security department only. Clicking on the Submit button will update the visualisation accordingly to the filter selections.



Figure 5: Location Transaction Tab: Filter Selection



3.2 Main Visualisation Panel
3.2.1 Heatmap of Location Visit Frequency
The interactive heatmap visualisation displays the frequency of location visit based on the credit card and loyalty card transactions history. The color intensity of the heatmap represents the visit count for each location.
Figure 6 demonstrates the interactivity of the heatmap. User is able to drill down on any particular period by drag and selecting the area. Hovering over each square will display micro information, including the exact visit frequency count.



Figure 6: Heatmap: Location Visit Frequency By Date



3.2.2 Boxplot of Credit Card Transactions
The interactive boxplot visualisation displays the credit card transaction value for each location and the outliers shaded in red.
Figure 7 demonstrates the interactivity of the boxplot. User can hover to display the individual transaction with the median spending shown for the location on the boxplot. User is able to drill down on any particular area by drag and selecting the area.



Figure 7: Boxplot: Credit Card Transaction Boxplot



3.2.3 Barplot of Number of Transactions per Day per Location
The interactive barplot visualisation displays the credit card transaction frequency per day for each location colored by time period.
Figure 8 demonstrates the interactivity of the barplot. User can hover over the each bar section to display the micro data of each day within the time period.



Figure 8: Barplot: Number of Transactions per Day by Location



4.0 Card Mapping
The interactive parallel coordinate plot in figure 9 displays the credit card and loyalty card transactions. The filter on the left panel allows user to select multiple Credit Card numbers for display in the right panel. The main panel on the right displays a DataTable of the credit card and loyalty card owners detail at the top and the parallel coordinate visualisation at the bottom.
The parallel coordinate plots has 4 verticals: 1. Credit Card Transaction Date 2. Loyalty Card Transaction Date 3. Location of transaction 4. Price difference between credit card and loyalty card transaction
User can drag and select the verticals on the interactive Parallel Coordinate Visualisation to highlight only the transactions as per figure 9,



Figure 9: Parallel Coordinate Plot: Credit Card and Loyalty Card Mapping



5.0 Network Analysis
The tab displays two network analysis of Employee and the location based on their credit card transactions or car GPS movement.
5.1 Network Analysis by Credit Card Transaction
On the left side panel, five filters are available for user to select multiple inputs to change the network graph. Location, Employee, Time Period and Department are drop down filters with multiple selection available. Date is a range filter between 6 January 2014 to 19 January 2014. Clicking on the Submit button will update the visualisation accordingly to the filter selections.
On the right side panel, the interactive network analysis shows the interaction between employees and the location they patronise based on their credit card transaction data. Users can click the nodes to highlight all interaction edges linked to the node. For example, user can click on a locations nodes to display all interaction edges to employees nodes whom has made transaction at the location. Alternatively, user can change the node selection from the drop down bar labelled Select by id to select a particular employee or location. User can select different group of nodes categorised by their department or the location. Figure 10 shows the network analysis.



Figure 10: Network Analysis Tab: Network Analysis by Location and Employee via Credit Card Transactions



5.2 Network Analysis by employee car GPS locations
On the left side panel, the five filters are identical to the network analysis by credit card transaction with the addition of few more option for location selection. The locations are based on the employees car GPS stop location and it includes their residential address and suspicious meeting point with no point of interest nearby.
User can filter and select the interactive network analysis visualisation similar to the previous section. Figure 11 displays the interactive aspects of the network analysis visualisation.



Figure 11: Network Analysis Tab: Network Analysis by Location and Employee via car GPS locationS
